body: RUSSIANS OFTEN SEEM TO think of America in terms of opposites. There are greedy millionaires and the penniless homeless. There are the whites who have cars, personal computers and suburban homes, and there are the oppressed blacks. There are the militaristic and callous ruling circles led by President Reagan and ''the monopolies,'' and there are
title: HOW WE SEE EACH OTHER; THE VIEW FROM RUSSIA

body: For the adventurous diner, New York has never offered so many temptations. Where else can you eat Afghan, Czechoslovak, Ukrainian, Brazilian and French food on successive nights? New Yorkers learn at an early age that the staff of life is not necessarily a slice of white bread but also bagels and croissants, pita and poori, tacos and injera. The
title: ETHNIC BOUNTY

body: THEY BEGIN ARRIVING HOURS EARLY, as they always do, filling the Brooklyn courtroom. A woman in a sari, a man in the black cloak of Hasidism, people in denim and people in silk, faces of every hue from ebony to alabaster - all are assembling to take the oath of citizenship. In the second row sits Fritz Potier, formerly of Port-au-Prince, Haiti, and
title: THE NEW NEW YORKERS

body: FOR THE COOK WHO loves ethnic food, New York is a vast, rich, fascinating marketplace, where Polish dried mushrooms and Chinese winter melons, Mexican blue cornmeal and Vietnamese nuoc mam (fermented fish sauce) exist side by side in neighborhood markets Successive waves of newcomers have given New York foodways a unique character: Brazilian food
title: FOOD SHOPS; IN PURSUIT OF THE PERFECT INGREDIENT

body: A map of New York's ethnic groups resembles a map of the tangled Balkans; it is impossible to account for everyone. This map is based on the latest United States census, material from the Department of City Planning and other demographic data. Although it is large enough to convey an accurate overall picture of ethnic New York, it is too small to
title: WHO LIVES WHERE

body: WHEN NEW YORKERS of a certain age, no matter what their ethnic origin or their station in life, speak of ''eating Chinese,'' a second-floor restaurant in Chinatown is the sort of place they mean. Here meals can last hours, and between courses unhurried and sometimes weighty talk can ensue. It's not exactly an evening at Virginia Woolf's, but then
title: EATING WITH THEIR MOUTHS OPEN

body: In Britain in the late 1800's, the waving of a red flag in the road signaled the approach of a ''devil machine'' or automobile. When the ''red flag laws'' were dropped in 1886, motorists toured from London to Brighton, gleefully ripping red flags along the way. The sixth Brighton Run-American Style will be held, minus the red flags, tomorrow
title: Auto-Rally Plans Vintage-Car Procession

body: ONCE, long ago, there was to be a Verrazano Street in Greenwich Village. City maps show it curving gracefully through existing parcels of developed land from Seventh Avenue across Downing Street to the foot of Bedford Street at the Avenue of the Americas, snipping off a backyard here and a piece of a building there. The snippets were taken by the
title: Perspectives: Land Divestitures; Disposing of City-Owned Property

body: Hurricane Gloria charged up the Atlantic seaboard yesterday and slammed into the New York metropolitan region with pounding winds and heavy rains. Long Island and Connecticut bore the brunt, but most of the region appeared to take the awesome storm in stride. The hurricane - 300 miles of churning spiral arms that hurled winds up to 130 miles an
title: HURRICANE POUNDS NEW YORK REGION: DAMAGE MODERATE; 280,000 FLEE HOMES

body: IT is only a 30-minute bus ride from the Five Towns Senior Center in Hewlett to the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn. But for the 40 members of the senior center and their guests who took a bus and walking tour there recently, it seemed like a trip to another country. title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL; BRIGHTON BEACH MEMOIR

body: SING ALONG WITH ASTI Beginning tonight, Asti, the restaurant that has been a landmark in Greenwich Village since 1925, is celebrating its 60th year with an opening program that features ''a tuneful musical feast served with Northern Italian cuisine.'' The Asti Singers - joined by waiters, bartenders, doormen, hatcheck girls and patrons - include
title: GOING OUT GUIDE

body: EVERYONE, drug dealers excepted, seems to love the recent renovation of Union Square Park. The park, which dates to 1833, has probably never looked so gloriously open, light and inviting and, nearby residents seem to agree, the results have been well worth the year and over $3 million that the Parks Department restoration took. Elizabeth Schick now
title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

body: An elderly Queens couple died of botulism last week after eating a salted white fish called kapchonka, the city's Health Department said yesterday. Theirs were the first New York City cases of botulism in recent memory, according to Dr. David J. Sencer, the Health Commissioner. He placed an immediate embargo on the sale and distribution of the
title: 2 DEATHS TRACED TO BOTULISM

body: Even if he didn't have to get soaking wet on stage every night, I would still feel sorry for Don Correia, the unlucky performer cast as the hero of Broadway's extravagant adaptation of Hollywood's classic musical ''Singin' in the Rain.'' While ''42d Street'' tells us that tap dancers can go out on a Broadway stage as nobodies and come back as
title: THEATER VIEW; CASTING CAN MAKE OR BREAK A SHOW

body: A four-car BMT subway train derailed yesterday morning shortly after pulling out of the DeKalb Avenue station in downtown Brooklyn. Five people, including a 4-month-old girl, were treated for suspected smoke inhalation and sprains, and a pregnant woman went to the hospital with labor pains, the Transit Authority reported. All were taken to Brooklyn
title: M TRAIN DERAILS NEAR A STATION; FIVE ARE INJURED

body: Rabbi Osias Horowitz of the Beth Hamedrosh Hagodol Synagogue in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn died Sunday at Beth Israel Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 90 years old and lived in Brooklyn. Rabbi Horowitz was born to the family of a rabbi in Poland. He came to the United States, at the age of 34, as the synagogue's first rabbi. Despite
title: RABBI OSIAS HOROWITZ

body: WHATEVER the weather, I will spend a good part of today at West End Beach 2. Just as I did last Father's Day, I will run two miles (along the shore), body surf in the ocean and sit on the sand, dreaming and planning. title: LONG ISLAND OPINION; LIFE WITH FATHER: ON THE BEACH...

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE

body: WHEN DAVID RABE'S first play, ''The Basic Training of Pavlo Hummel,'' was performed at New York's Public Theater, Neil Simon was already up to play No. 11 - ''The Prisoner of Second Avenue'' - and counting. title: THE CRAFT OF THE PLAYWRIGHT

title: THE MAKING OF A SCENE IN NEIL SIMON'S ''BILOXI BLUES''

title: PERSPECTIVES: THE M.C.I. PROGRAM; Paying for Capital Improvements

body: A 95-year-old man was stabbed to death, apparently by a burglar, in the bedroom of his fifth-floor apartment in a large apartment house in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn. The body of the victim, Irving Bernstein of 150 Corbin Place, was found by his son, Marvin, at 4:30 P.M. with ''numerous'' stab wounds, the police said. Mr. Bernstein, who
title: 95-Year-Old Stabbed To Death in Brooklyn

body: as Cornishmen have been doing for generations - they take with them for sustenance rich and filling savory pies called Cornish pasties, which they pronounce with a broad ''a'' - PAHS- tees. Each one is just large enough to fit in a worker's hand. They are made of leftover meat, chopped with potatoes, mixed with gravy, sealed in a pastry envelope
title: SAVORY PIES: A WORLDWIDE COOK'S TOUR

body: To say that a dream came true with the back-to-back Broadway openings of Peter Nichols's ''Joe Egg'' and Neil Simon's ''Biloxi Blues'' is not to indulge in idle rhetoric. The dream that came true was an actual dream - the one in which the dreamer runs into some old friends and discovers, to his amazement, that the familiar faces and personalities
title: DON'T LOOK NOW, BUT THERE'S NEW LIFE ON BROADWAY

body: Although the laughter rarely stops in ''Biloxi Blues,'' Neil Simon's joyous and unexpectedly rewarding new comedy, the most surprising line of the evening by far is not a joke, but a reprimand. The reprimand is delivered to the young hero, Eugene Je rome (Matthew Broderick) - who has now graduated from the Depression adolescence of Mr. Simon's
title: STAGE: 'BILOXI BLUES,' SIMON'S NEW COMEDY

body: Two men were killed and a firefighter was injured last night in a blaze that fire officials described as suspicious at a factory and residential building in the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn, authorities said. The bodies of the two men, who were still unidentifed early this morning, were discovered in a third floor apartment at 3089 Brighton
title: 2 Die in Brighton Beach Fire That Officials Call Suspicious

body: There is a smile on Fred Thompson's face. ''Mary, get in with them and run,'' he scolds a 14-year-old. ''No, it's going to hurt me,'' she says, an angry look playing over her face. ''C'mon, Mary, run, run,'' shout other women. Reluctantly, driven as much by Thompson's stare as her small feet, she gets into the pack for the start of the first of
title: PROVING GROUND FOR FLEET WOMEN

body: STANDING gaunt and empty at the by law northern corner of a vacant construction site on Lexington Avenue between 43d and 44th Street is a venerable structure that once was called the Terminal Hotel. title: CITY'S DEMOLITION MORATORIUM CHILLS DEVELOPMENT

body: ''USUALLY the most creative thing a writer does is figuring out why not to write or what to do instead of writing,'' said Alan Zweibel. By that standard, the 34-year-old Mr. Zweibel, who did most of his growing up in Wantagh and Woodmere and now lives in Manhattan, hasn't been too creative lately. title: LONG ISLANDERS; DELI? HE'S SLICED IT; COMEDY? HE'S WRITTEN IT

body: IF someone had called central casting requesting one sweet little old lady, Alan Rosenberg remembers thinking, she couldn't have been more perfect than the one who stood on line in front of him one recent weekend afternoon to see ''Beverly Hills Cop.'' title: METROPOLITAN DIARY

body: Markets Staying Open The end of the calendar year has traditionally marked the end of the city's Greenmarket year as well. In the past, with the exception of the Saturday market at Union Square, farmers and suppliers of the neighborhood outdoor markets have packed up at the onset of severe weather and gone home to winter on farms in the Hudson
